turn.1: What are the main features of Proto-Germanic language?

turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: It was found in various environments: Another form of alternation was triggered by the Germanic spirant law, which continued to operate into the separate history of the individual daughter languages.
turn.6: It is found in environments with suffixal -t, including:  An alternation not triggered by sound change was Sievers' law, which caused alternation of suffixal -j- and -ij- depending on the length of the preceding part of the morpheme.
turn.7: What were some of the suffixes?
turn.8: If preceded within the same morpheme by only short vowel followed by a single consonant, -j- appeared.
turn.9: What else did you find interesting?
turn.10: In all other cases, such as when preceded by a long vowel or diphthong, by two or more consonants, or by more than one syllable, -ij- appeared.
turn.12: The distinction between morphemes and words is important here, as the alternant -j- appeared also in words that contained a distinct suffix that in turn contained -j- in its second syllable.
